definitions.definition: necessary or essential in order for something to succeed or exist
definitions.sensetop: vital for somebody/somethingvital to somethingit is vital that…it is vital to do somethingit is vital for somebody/something to do something

examples.text: the vitamins that are vital for health
Patience and a cool head are vital for investors.
Good financial accounts are vital to the success of any enterprise.
Reading is **of vital importance** in language learning.
The police play **a vital role** in our society.
Small chemist shops are a **vital part** of many local communities.
'We are prepared to use force to protect our vital interests in the region,' he said
The website provides vital information for tourists.
It is vital that you keep accurate records when you are self-employed.
It was vital to show that he was not afraid.
examples.contextForm: it is vital to do something

examples.text: It is **absolutely vital** for cities to have public green spaces.
examples.contextForm: it is vital for somebody/something to do something

examples.text: These nutrients are absolutely vital to good health.
fostering team spirit, which is vital for success
Bean sprouts contain many of the vitamins that are vital for health.

definitions.definition: connected with or necessary for staying alive

examples.text: the **vital organs** *(= the brain, heart, lungs, etc.)*

wordOrigin: late Middle English (describing the animating principle of living beings, also in sense (3)): via Old French from Latin vitalis, from vita ‘life’. The sense ‘essential’ dates from the early 17th cent.
